text.content:
Welcome to Foundry! If this is your first time in using the MgT2e system on Foundry, then there are probably lots of things that you want to know. This insn't going to be an introduction to Foundry, but it will guide you through some of the options that you may want to take a look at.

Currently, MgT2e supports both Foundry V12 and V13. These are slightly different in what options provide, and how they should be setup. Where there are differences, they will be mentioned.

Core Options

When you create a new world, you may want to first take a look at the Configure Settings option on the right hand sidebar. Click on the Core filter.

Configure Permissions

These control what players are able to do. You might find it useful lto allow players to create their own characters. If so, tick the box for the Create New Actors option for Players and Trusted Players.

V13 Only

The following options only apply to FoundryVTT v13.

Combat Turn Marker

Set to the mgt2e version.

Auto Rotate

Probably want to switch this off.

MgT2e Options

MgT2e has options of its own. Not all the options are listed, just the ones that are more important.

Year

The current year of the campaign. This is used when determining birth date and start age of Travellers. It default to 1105, so if you are playing a game in a different year, then you may want to change this.

Player sheet update broadcasts

When a player rolls their characteristics, or adds skills to their character sheet, a chat message is generated to describe the change. By default, this goes to the player that made the change, and the GM. This provides a record of the changes that have been made.

This is not only to keep players honest, but also makes it easier for modifications to be rolled back if they were done by mistake, or the players changes their mind.

This option can be changed to only send the message to the player, or to send it to everyone.

GM sheet update broadcasts

As for player sheet broadcasts, but this is for when the GM makes a change. It can either be private (GM only) or everyone.

Token vision

There is an option for Travellers, NPCs, Creatures and Vehicles (which includes spacecraft). If these are ticked, then when a new actor of that type is created, the prototype token will have their vision switched on. By default, tokens do not have vision.

If you tend to use tactical combat maps, then this may be useful.

Auto set player character

When a player creates an actor, if they do not currently have a default character set, then the new character will be set as their default.

By default, players cannot create actors, so they need to be given permission to do so (see above).

Having a default character set means that when macros are used which reference a skill or character, the default character will be used if no other character is selected.

Split attack and damage rolls

Normally, when attack rolls are made, the attack and damage roll are done at the same time. If you don't like this, and want to split them into two separate rolls, then enable this option.

MgT2e Options

MgT2e has options of its own. Not all the options are listed, just the ones that are more important.

Default to Quick Rolls

By default, when you click on a skill on a character sheet, a dialog will pop up allowing you to set the difficulty first. If you hold shift when clicking, the dialog will be skipped and a roll will be made with default options. Enable this option to reverse the behaviour, and make quick rolls the default, and requiring shift to be used to get the dialog.

Number of skill columns

By default, character sheets display skills in three columns. This can be switched to two for larger text, but is less compact.

Skill list format

Control whether skills are listed in columns (going down one column, then down the next column) or in rows (across one row, then across the next row).

Macro Hotbar

It is possible to add commony used items to the hotbar at the bottom of the screen. There are some useful macros provided by default.

These macros are part of the MgT2e Base Macros compendium.

1D6, 2D6, D66

Roll 1D6, 2D6 or D66. Though these aren't hard to roll from the chat, they might be useful to have available as a single click option.

MgT2e Docs

A link to this documentation.

Actors

It is possible to add an actor to the hotbar by either dragging them from the sidebar, or by dragging their portrait from the character sheet. This provides a one-click way to access your character. If you have multiple characters, you can place all of them on the hot bar.

If you have the character set as your default, then pressing 'C' will also open your character's sheet.

GM Note: IYou might find it useful to have all the player characters added to your hotbar.

Skills

You can drag a skill from the character sheet to the hotbar as well. If you select the hot bar skill, then the currently selected token will roll the skill. If you don't have a token selected, then it will use your default character if it is set.

If it is a skill with specialities, only the parent is dragged. However, when you use the skill, it will roll all the specialities that you have points in together. This reduces the number of skills you need to put on the hot bar.

GM Note: Since the skill is rolled for the currently selected actor token, you can place common skills on the hotbar. When an actor token needs to make a skill check, you can select them and just simply click the skill.

The Traveller sheet is used by players to record information about their charactors.

Rolling Characteristics

For a new Traveller, there are several ways to roll characteristics.

  1. You can type [[/r 2D6 # Roll Characteristic]]{/r 2D6} six times in the chat window, and manually insert the values into your character sheet.

  2. You can type /uwp into the chat window, which will roll six characteristics for you. You can then drag the results to your character sheet. You can add a number to the end (such as /uwp 2) to roll extra sets of dice. The output will always be the highest six rolls.

  3. You can click the dice icon to the top right of your characteristics. This will roll each of the characteristics. This is the recommended option for new characters, because if you have non-default characteristics enabled, then these will be rolled as well. When you roll your characteristics in this way, the results will be sent to the chat, giving you and the Referee a record of what was rolled.

Once you have rolled your characteristics, you can drag them around to re-order them. So if you rolled a 6 in STR and a 12 in SOC, and you want to play a strong lower class character, you can drag SOC to STR, and the two values will be swapped.

Different Roll Options

If you hold down shift when clicking the dice option, then average dice will be rolled. This makes it less likely to get extreme values such as 2 or 12 (for each characteristic, five set of rolls will be made, and the middle one chosen).

This option is more useful for the Referee, who might want to generate a more 'average' set of NPCs.

If you hold down ctrl when clicking the dice option, the current values will be modified betweeen -2 and +2. So if they are all currently 7, then they will range between 5 and 9. Again, this is an option for the Referee. If you have a set of template NPCs (such as security guards), and you want them all to have slightly different characteristics, this option can be used.

Skills

Characteristics and skills can be rolled by clicking on them. When a skill is rolled, a dialog is popped up allowing you to select the difficulty, roll type (if it is a Boon or Bane) and any dice modifiers. If you hold down SHIFT when rolling a skill, the dialog will be skipped, and default values will be used.

Each skill has a default characteristic. You can change the characteristic each time you roll a skill. If you tick the 'Remember characteristic' option, then the characteristic you use this time will be remembered as the default for the next roll of this skill.

Specialities

Specialities are rolled in the same way as individual skills. However, you can also roll the parent skill that has multiple specialities. If you do, then the parent skill result will be displayed, as will the result of all the specialities. Only a single dice roll is made, but the total for each speciality will be shown.

Using the Hotbar

You can drag actors and skills to the hotbar, for quick access later.

Player Video Guide

For referees who want to customise what skills and characteristics are used in their campaign, there are a number of options available.

Default Traveller

Through the world configuration, there is a setting for defining a Default Traveller. If this is set, then when an actor is created, the system will look for a Traveller with the defined name.

Note that this is a name, not a uuid, and has to be in the world. It can't be in a compendium.

The default actor will be used for the following:

  • The list of characteristics will be used by default. Set which characteristics you want to use on the default actor, and these will be set on any new actors created.

  • The list of skills will be used as well. If you modify the skill list on the default actor, then this skill list will be used for:

    • The list of skills for any new actors when they are created.

    • The list of skills for drop down menus. If selecting skills to use with a weapon, or with augments or computer software, then the skills from the default actor will be used instead of the normal defaults.

This means that if you are wanting to use skills or characteristics from the Traveller Compendium for example, then you just need to set them up once on a Default Traveller, and they will be applied to any new actors.

Packages

Packages are a type of actor that are designed to be used as templates for Travellers and NPCs. They are not meant to be used as active characters within a campaign, but applied as templates to modify an existing actor.

You can:

  • Set modifiers for characteristics. When the Package is applied, the +/- modifiers will be applied for each characteristic.

  • Set skills. If a skill is set on the Package, when it is applied to an actor, the skills will be added to those on the actor. If the Package as 'Admin 1', and the actor has 'Admin 2', then after adding the Package, the actor will then have 'Admin 3'.

  • Add careers, allies, enemies etc to Travellers. For NPCs, the NPCs age is increased, but the career won't actually be added.

  • Add equipment.

  • Add cash, if set on the Package.

Racial Package

If the 'Racial Package' tick box is selected, then the Package is turned into a Racial Package.

  • Rather than adding bonuses to characteristics, the characteristics set on the Package need to be dice values. They default to 2D6. When the Package is added to a Traveller or NPC actor, that actor's characteristics will be rolled.

  • The target actor will remember what dice types were set. So if you click the dice symbol to re-roll the actor's characteristics, it will re-roll using the dice settings from the Package. If STR was set to 2D3+6, then it will always use 2D3+6 on re-roll.

A racial package is designed to allow different characteristic values for non-human species.

Other Uses of Racial Package

You can also use racial packages to define different distributions of characteristics for NPCs. For example, if you wanted to setup a package for a human street thug, you might set a Package to have characteristics like the following:

STR 2D3+5, DEX 2D3+4, END 2D3+4, INT 2D3+2, EDU 2D3, SOC 1D3

This would give above normal physical traits, and below normal mental and social traits.
